Description: Mould-made amuletic figure in glazed composition, representing a lion-headed deity, difficult to identify (maybe Khons-Thot?); wearing a headdress composed of full moon and crescent; standing in striding pose on a rectangular base, with arms to the sides, leaning against back pillar; roughly made with crude features; suspension hole pierced widthways in the back pillar behind the head; pale yellowish green glaze mostly decayed; front lower part is broken off (feet and forepart of the base).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Though at first sight, a female breast seems to be marked, indicating that it would be a Sekhmet, several other details rather indicate that it must be a representation of a male deity: large shoulders, short kilt, lunar disc on top of the head-dress with the crescent moon well marked under it. It could be a representation of Khonsu, possibly the local Naukratite Khons-Thot.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.172) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather fair, though glaze mostly decayed and lower part broken off
Previous owner: Currently owned by: World Museum, Liverpool
